title: Winterbourne Walk Route

images.title: Nigel Thompson / Winterbourne railway station (site), Gloucestershire
images.caption: Winterbourne railway station (site), Gloucestershire Opened in 1903 by the Great Western Railway on the line from Swindon to the Severn Tunnel, this station closed in 1963. View east towards Coalpit Heath and Swindon, as the electrification masts were going up.

images.title: Graham Richards / Viaduct
images.caption: Viaduct over the Frome. The footbridge is, however, clearly in the next square to the north. The viaduct carries the trains on the line between London and Wales via Bristol Parkway 3 km away to the west.

images.title: Steve Coffin / Damsons Bridge Winterbourne Down
images.caption: Damsons Bridge

images.title: Don Ford / River Frome at Frenchay
images.caption: River Frome at Frenchay. The River Frome flows for 18 miles to join the Avon in the centre of Bristol. It powered a number of mills along its length

images.title: Paul Harvey / Weir on River Frome-Oldbury Court
images.caption: Weir on River Frome-Oldbury Court

images.caption: Bridge over the River Frome

images.caption: Snuff Mills restored mill

images.title: 2011 : River Frome from Damsons Bridge by Maurice Pullin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Frome from Damsons Bridge

description: This riverside village is located just north of Bristol and east of Yate in Gloucestershire. It's an interesting place for a stroll with a picturesque fishing pond, a noteworthy 12th century church, a 14th century Tithe Barn and Huckford Quarry, a public nature reserve popular with dog walkers. This walk from the village takes you south along a section of the Frome Valley Walkway to the historic Snuff Mills and Oldbury Court Estate. It's a very pleasant stretch of the river passing the interesting villages of Hambrook and Frenchay on the way. The route starts on the eastern side of the village where you can cross the river near the Viaduct on a footbridge. You can then follow the waymarked footpath south along the river passing Winterbourne Down, Damsons Bridge, Hambrook and Frenchay. Here you can explore the Woodland Trust's Frenchay Moor where there's some pleasant trails next to the historic village and Frenchay Common. From here it is a short walk to Snuff Mills where you will find a picturesque 19th century mill and some nice trails around the parkland on the Oldbury Court Estate.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Community Forest Path runs through the village. The long distance trail takes you on a tour of some of the walking highlights surrounding the city of Bristol. Just west of Yate there's the worthy village of Iron Acton. Here you'll find an historic church, riverside walks, a lovely garden centre and a noteworthy pub dating back to the 17th century.

display_address: Hicks Common Road, Winterbourne, Winterbourne Down, South Gloucestershire, West of England, England, BS36 1EJ, United Kingdom
